we show our theoretical specific heat at constant pressure, C
. For clarity, the error bars of the observed data are not included in the plot but can be found in the
original report. However, the theoretical C
values are safely within all these error bars and the agreement is very
favorable, suggesting that our calculated phonon density of states is rather accurate as well.
The monoclinic structure that defines the
phase of plutonium is quite remarkable. Not only is it without com-
parison, but the large monoclinic cell has sites that are very different from each other. Most glaring is the site for
) that is located in a more open space than the other types, see
. Consequently, the local electronic structure is significantly different between the atom types and particu-
larly so for atom number 8. In Fig.
we show our calculated atom-projected electronic density of states
focusing on the features at the Fermi level, it is clear that this atom is different than all the others. One may hypoth-
esize that the phonon properties are affected anomalously due to the contribution from this prominent 8
we plot the local atom-projected phonon density of states for atom types 2 and 8. We recognize
immediately that type 8 has high-energy vibrational states that are completely absent for type 2. None of the other
atom types have similar intensity at high energies (not shown). Therefore, atom 8 is mostly responsible for the
18–20 meV region of the phonon density of states for
-plutonium. Interestingly, this high-energy feature is very
different from the phonon density of states of
-plutonium (face-centered cubic) that has no intensity at all above
. It is apparent that good phonon properties of
-plutonium can only be modeled by a theory that
correctly captures the unusual behavior of the special atom number 8.
We divide the Methods section into two parts, because our calculations naturally fall into separate categories.
First, we focus on the density-functional theory and the electronic structure that is employed for calculat-
ing forces on displaced atoms. The electronic structure is constructed from a full-potential linear muffin-tin
that is fully relativistic but also includes an extension with an orbital-polarization contribu-
. It is derived from atomic physics that is known to be an important perturbation of the 5f-electron states
specific heat at constant pressure, C
